conbody.p: specify protections for cell-level security control?

The PHEMI Central DPF system enables the tagging of derived data elements with privacy protections. Available privacy protections are configured in the PHEMI Management Console by an Administrator, and are then available for DPFs to tag data with context specific protections. For instance, the SSN extracted from a health record object may be tagged as CONFIDENTIAL.

Privacy tags (called Data Attributes in PHEMI Central) can then be combined with rules around user properties (such as Doctor or Analyst) to control access to data of a specific sensitivity. For instance, an Administrator may create a rules (called an Access Policy) that grants READ access to user's that are Doctors for data that is CONFIDENTIAL. They can then attach this Access Policy to a set of data, such as a collection of health records.

This approach to data protection is called Attribute Based Access Control (ABAC) and is a more general version of the more commonly used Role Based Access Control (RBAC). An ABAC approach is advantageous when not all uses/access controls around data are known up front and when new types of data may be introduced into the system -- both common scenarios in healthcare, where data evolves and changes as well as the allowed use of data.

Attribute Based Access Control Users can be tagged with attributes that describe their level of authorization. Data can be tagged with attributes that describe its level of sensitivity or its requirements for privacy. Together, these two attributes can be combined to allow sophisticated access privileges to identified, unidentifiable, deidentified, or anonymized data.
